title: EU court top lawyer sides with Poland on judicial independence
text:
A demonstration in support of Supreme Court judges in Warsaw, in 2018. In 2017, Law and Justice government revamped rules for disciplining judges | Janek Skarzynski/AFP via Getty Images EU court top lawyer sides with Poland on judicial independence Non-binding opinion on questions from judges finds the danger of undermining their independence ‘remains hypothetical.’

Questions from two Polish courts to the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) over whether a new system of disciplining judges in the country violates EU law shouldn’t be admitted, the court's advocate general said Tuesday in a non-binding opinion.

Polish judges had expressed concern that if they rule against Polish government institutions in criminal or administrative proceedings, they might face disciplinary action.

In 2017, the right-wing Law and Justice government revamped rules for disciplining judges, bringing the system under tight political control. The judges asked the EU's highest court if those new disciplinary rules are in line with EU law.

If the CJEU finds that the new disciplinary system breaches EU rules, the Polish government would have to drop it.

But in today’s opinion, the court’s advocate general, Evgeni Tanchev, said that due to procedural reasons, these questions shouldn’t be addressed by the court. He said there hasn’t been “sufficient explanation of the relationship between the relevant provisions of EU law and the Polish measures in question,” and “the question whether there is a structural breach of judicial independence … remains hypothetical in the circumstances of the main proceedings.”

That reasoning followed the line of argument taken by the Polish government during a hearing in June.

The opinion is non-binding but usually constitutes the base for the final judgement, which is expected by the end of this year.

The Luxembourg court will have another chance to decide whether Poland’s new disciplinary model is in line with EU law. In April, the European Commission started another infringement procedure against Warsaw, saying the new system “undermines the judicial independence of Polish judges and does not ensure the necessary guarantees to protect judges from political control.”
description: Non-binding opinion on questions from judges finds the danger of undermining their independence ‘remains hypothetical.’
